data.title: Ralph Nader joins the presidential race
data.text:
Ralph Nader has announced that he will be a candidate in this year's US presidential race, running as an independent.

It's not the first time he has thrown his hat in the ring. In the 2000 election he was accused by many Democrats of stealing their votes and allowing George Bush to take the White House.

Mr Nader has been an influential figure in American public life for 40 years.

The 74-year-old campaigns against what he sees as corporate greed and wasteful defence spending as well as championing consumer rights and the need to protect the environment.

His supporters argue that he is a kind of grassroots visionary whose ideas start life on the fringes of political debate then move to the centre, but he achieved only 2.74% of the popular vote in 2000.

So what is the point of him running again this time?

Listen Listen to Ralph Nader

So could Mr Nader's candidacy draw crucial votes away from the left and help the Republican party in this year's elections?

Or was Mr Nader's part in Al Gore's defeat overblown? Bob Zelnick is a political commentator and author of a biography on Al Gore.

Listen Listen to Bob Zelnick

First broadcast 24th and 25th February
